recent_headlines: The future of AI is going to depend on your hardware

sample_openings: The media has always been at the centre of the AI explosion and while last year it looked like it was taking serious hits, in 2025 it showed that there was a willingness to embrace AI and double down on quality journalism that holds the powerful to account. Here are the lessons learnt from the workDevelop AIhas done this year around the world.

I was in Copenhagen last week, which is a lovely theme park type of city. I was speaking at IMS’sCopenhagen Conference on Information Integrityon a panel about AI and the future of media. One of my fellow panellists was the Danish Tech Ambassador, Anne Marie Engtoft Meldgaard. She was the first in the world to hold this kind of position and she had just come from the US where everyone she spoke to was obsessed with AIG (the development of a super intelligence that will replace us all). In contrast, the tone and incredible calibre of speakers at the conference (which took place at UN City) made me feel like the EU is focused on the moral and humane use of tech in the world and how we can harness it for good.
It is always good to let the relentless wave of AI text-to-video hype wash over you and then check in every few months on what the actual quality is looking like.
Versions of these stories first appeared on my LinkedIn newsletter,Develop AI Daily.
These stories first appeared on my daily LinkedIn newsletter,Develop AI Daily.

Please welcome the return of our podcast "Burn It Down" which will, going forward, focus exclusively on AI and education.
A version of this article was originally published byPublic Media Alliance.

For the longest time I have told people, “I’m not a coder. I use ChatGPT.” But that has begun to change. I still use ChatGPT for help, but I am getting a tighter grip every day on how software is built and what it is capable of.

I remember when my PC began to search the actual words inside my Word documents rather than just the titles of my files… it was a complete game changer. It felt like this evolution in search would solve all of my life’s problems. But now, decades later, I just feel like I am drowning in Zoom call recordings and endless WhatsApp group images. The most exciting part of the AI revolution, for me, is that we will finally have order and insights from all this data we have been collecting.

NEVER use generic cliches or corporate speak - be specific, direct, and authentic

sample_openings: I remember when RAM was a birthday treat. Because simply better hardware meant better games. But as a byproduct you learnt how to open up your Pentium and where to fit in the RAM and how the other components worked (and where they would need upgrading). That was the last time I really thought about computer chips. Since then I’ve relied on my phone and a series of Macbooks and trusted that Moore’s Law and Steve Jobs would take care of everything else. But the latest chip announcements from AMD and the news that AI tools are going to start demanding more from our machines has meant I’m back to thinking about the chips in our laptops again. Here is what I’ve learnt.

sample_reader_questions: What do you have that others don’t?
But when you duplicate that private use millions of times where does that leave the creators of the "source material"?
And if the source of your insights is a black-box model with unclear logic, how do you defend your reporting?

We talk about this issue a great deal while I’m training newsrooms in AI: if you declare that a piece of content was created with AI can you be sure that your audience will fully appreciate what that means in a world where “AI” has become synonymous with “fake”?
If you wilfully document and sell your voice for scraps then surely you are giving up a major part of your IP?
If you are admitting to your audience (and the algorithm) that you are using generative AI and suffering those consequences in perception then why not push it as far as you can?

In the news…
The brilliant technologist and human rights advocate Sam Gregory gives a terrifying (and ultimately uplifting)
Ted Talk
titled “When AI can fake reality, who can you trust?
